Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Long-term Interactions among Biodiversity, CO2, and N in a Perennial Grassland Ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid human-caused increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentrations during the next 50 years will contribute to global warming and will likely shift precipitation patterns and/or amounts, influencing the growth and performance of vegetation worldwide. Plants and their ecosystems absorb roughly one-fourth of the CO2 emitted from fossil fuel combustion each year, and it is critical to understand whether plants can continue this important function as CO2 levels continue to rise. There are fewer than five realistic long-term field experiments that test whether vegetation will continue to absorb extra carbon, and whether such carbon capture may be constrained by infertile soils, lack of soil moisture, climate warming, or loss of diversity. The BioCON experiment is one of these, where plants are exposed to CO2 levels expected to occur late in the 21st century. Since 1998 BioCON has examined interactions among biodiversity, atmospheric CO2, and soil N supply in a temperate perennial grassland in Minnesota. BioCON includes precipitation manipulation (begun in 2007) and warming treatments (begun in 2012). This project will support this experiment from 2012-2017, including measures of plants and soils relevant to both ecosystem science and atmospheric change.

This research will address issues of major importance to society, in particular the potential impacts of human activities on environmental processes at local to global scales. The degrees to which loss of diversity, climate warming, soil nitrogen, and soil moisture constrain the long-term ability of ecosystems to capture and sequester carbon will also be examined. In addition, because it is a unique facility open to and encouraging new initiatives, BioCON will enhance research and education and promote teaching, training, and learning for students, teachers, journalists and others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This LTREB project supported the world's longest-running, multi-factor global change experiment.  The experiment manipulates plant biodiversity, elevated CO2, enriched nitrogen, temperature and rainfall across 371 perennial grassland plots, making up a series of related sub-experiments involving various combinations of those five factors. A number of major findings emerged from this work.

First, we discovered that multiple resource limitation can reduce or even eliminate the fertilization of biomass due to elevated CO2. Plots at ambient nitrogen supply showed an initial transient biomass response (1998-2000), responding as much to elevated CO2 as did plots under enriched nitrogen, but thereafter their response was half as large, at least partially due to different long-term CO2 impacts on N cycling in ambient versus N enriched treatments (Reich and Hobbie 2013). Plots at both ambient nitrogen supply and reduced rainfall showed no growth enhancement due to rising CO2 (Reich et al 2014), likely due to nitrogen and water limitation being dominant in that combination of treatments, making carbon limitation small enough to be undetectable. 

Second, we observed that soil communities varied in response to global change treatments (Deng et al 2016). Food webs in this ecosystem were more sensitive to differences in plant diversity than in elevated CO2 and N deposition (Eisenhauer et al 2013), and could vary more due to variation within than across trophic levels (Cesarz et al 2015). We also found that soil fungal and N2-fixing communities responded to elevated CO2 via community reassembly (Tu et al 2015, 2017) and that plant functional differences could drive differences in soil N cycling, and thus feedback to the CO2 responses, ostensibly through such shifts (Terrer et al 2018).

Third, we learned much about processes influencing competition, co-existence, and differential responses among plant functional groups under elevated CO2.  Traits strongly influence these responses (Ali et al 2015). Additionally, long-term feedbacks on soil N cycling of different functional groups appear to drive long-term flips in responsiveness to elevated CO2 of C3 versus C4 grasses (Reich et al 2018).  This latter study was wholly unexpected and highlights that long-term feedbacks within ecosystems can make predictions based on short-term biology inaccurate; a sobering cautionary tale for modeling.

Fourth, results from this study provide the backbone (due to long time frame, high replication, and multiple global change treatments) of a number of multi-experiment syntheses about global change impacts. These include meta-analyses and syntheses about elevated CO2 (Andresen et al 2016), warming (Andresen et al 2016, Carey et al 2016), and biodiversity (Hungate et al 2017, Isbell et al 2018).
